data.name: St. Gallen Bridge Trail
data.abstract: St. Gallen has more bridges than do most other cities in Switzerland. The Bridge Trail leads from the St.Gallen-Haggen Station and over 18 bridges.
data.description: This 7.5 kilometre walking trail starts at the train station in St. Gallen-Haggen and goes to Spisegg. The trail runs past eighteen viaducts, wooden and concrete bridges and suspension bridges and through the river landscape in the Sitter- und Wattbachlandschaft nature reserve. An information board at each bridge explains much about the design, year of construction and the construction itself.

data.name: St.Gallen Sausage
data.abstract: The queen among 400 Swiss sausages
data.description: The culinary pride of the locals, the St.Gallen Sausage, was invented as early as 1438. 300 years later, it was patented as the Olma sausage. Its soft and white inner core is composed of veal meat and some pork bacon. As well as milk. In St. Gallen they are traditionally eaten without mustard, because this covers the nuances of the exquisite meat. At parties, football matches and as streetfood, you can enjoy the golden-brown sausage from the grill together with a crispy St. Gallen Bürli. Gourmets order the sausage flawlessly white from the brew to savour and passionately discuss the compositions of their favourite butchers with all their nuances.

data.name: St. Gallen Weiherweg (Three Ponds Trail)
data.abstract: Should you choose to make your way to the Three Ponds, then a leisurely stroll high above the roofs of St.Gallen awaits you.
data.description: Throughout this walk you'll feast your eyes on the breathtaking views, and in summer you might even work up the courage to take a dip in the cool water. The easiest way to reach the starting point of this walk is with the Mühleggbahn (the base station behind the abbey district).

data.name: St. Gallen Theatre
data.abstract: Switzerland's oldest recorded professional theatre and the only multifunctional venue in the Eastern Switzerland/Lake Constance region has a long history.
data.description:
Instigated by the Benedictine monks Tutilo and Notker, theatre in St. Gallen began in the Middle Ages – and became professional in 1801. Since the end of the 1960s, the theatre has been permanently based in the Paillard building in the museum district, with more than 200 performances a year. 

Opera, drama, dance, musicals, children's and youth theatre are the main attractions at the St. Gallen Theatre. Performances for children and young people are held both at the theatre and in schools. Since 2010, the renovated Lokremise (locomotive depot) has provided a second permanent venue, offering space for productions that require an unconventional setting.

data.name: St.Gallen – city winter sports
data.abstract: With its four cross-country skiing trails, three ski lifts, one artificial and one natural ice rink, St.Gallen is justified in calling itself an urban winter sports resort. Thanks to its location at an altitude of 700m, the winter sports facilities are in operation for several weeks practically every winter.
data.description:
The Beckenhalde, Schlössli and Vögelinsegg ski lifts are open every day when snow conditions are good. In addition to operating during the day the lifts also offer night skiing and ski races. 

The four cross-country skiing trails on the outskirts of the city of St.Gallen (Unterer Brand, Notkersegg, Peter and Paul and Kinderfestplatz) provide great opportunities for exercising and training in natural surroundings. When snow conditions and the weather are good, the trails are regularly groomed for classic and skating style cross-country skiing. 

The natural ice rink on the Buebenweiher, the middle one of the famous Three Ponds, is a very special experience. When the ice is thick enough, the pond becomes a paradise for skaters of all ages. 

Those who prefer skating on artificial ice, will be delighted with the rink at the Lerchenfeld Ice Sports Centre. The ice rink there is open from September to April.

data.name: St.Gallen Panorama Tour
data.abstract: Enjoy the splendid panorama of St.Gallen with the Abbey District on this tour.
data.description: In summer, the «Drei Weieren» (three ponds) Art Nouveau bathhouses are the perfect place for a cool bath. Pass by meadows and forests as you cross various districts of the city of St.Gallen. Enjoy views of the city from a variety of different viewing spots.

data.name: Discovering St. Gallen by e-bike
data.abstract: On the two-and-a-half hour e-bike tour for groups through the city of St. Gallen, you’ll discover well-known and especially unknown sights in the Eastern Swiss metropolis.
data.description:
The guided bike tour through the city of St. Gallen takes in around eleven stops, at which you’ll learn from an experienced guide all about the important historical, cultural and architectural sights in the different areas of the city.

Click here for more information and dates: 
www.st.gallen-bodensee.ch [https://st.gallen-bodensee.ch/de/erlebnisse/fuehrungen/fuehrungen-in-st-gallen/stadt-in-bewegung-unterwegs-mit-dem-e-bike.html]

data.name: Lapidarium St.Gallen
data.abstract: Remnants of the Carolingian and Gothic churches that preceded the existing cathedral comprise the St.Gall's Lapidarium.
data.description: Capitols, architectural details and statuary date from the earlier 9th-century church and the medieval 16th-century edifice. Ask for a free English guide at the entrance.

data.name: Discover the St. Gallen region's culinary side
data.abstract: On a hike through the St. Gallen region, you can expect breathtaking views of Lake Constance as well as a host of culinary delicacies.
data.description:
This multifaceted culinary hike takes you from St.Gallen to the Rhine at the crossroads of four countries. Breathtaking views of Lake Constance await along with three culinary stops in first-class restaurants for hungry sightseers. 

After the first stage over flowering meadows and through shady forests, the Restaurant Bären serves a rich starter with local Gruber specialities. With new-found energy, you set off up to the Wirtschaft Rossbüchel restaurant and the observation deck with a panoramic view of five regions. 

Enjoy the regional delicacies and the spectacular view over Lake Constance and five regions: Switzerland, Austria and the formerly independent states of Baden, Württemberg and Bavaria. Bon appétit! Or as the Swiss say, En Guätä!

data.name: Guided Tours St. Gallen
data.abstract: Explore the city of St.Gallen on a public city tour and discover historical, surprising, and one-of-a-kind facts.
data.description:
The hidden corners, lively lanes and pretty houses form the perfect backdrop for a city or themed tour in UNESCO World Heritage City St.Gallen. Participants can discover why there are 111 bay windows here, learn the secret of the local beer’s unique flavour, or step into Switzerland’s biggest outdoor living-room. These are some of the tours to discover:

 * Guided tour of St.Gallen’s old town including Abbey Library and cathedrale: UNESCO World Heritage to marvel at
 * Crime scene St.Gallen: Time for eerily exciting stories
 * Out and about with a maidservant: A journey back in time to the 16th century

data.name: Christmas in St. Gallen
data.abstract: Around 700 stars twinkle above the squares and alleyways of St.Gallen's old town in December, bathing the historic facades of the UNESCO World Heritage town in a festive Christmas glow.
data.description:
Every year on November 30, the starry sky of St. Gallen is lit up in a festive way at the star vernissage. The stars twinkle and dance in a light choreography specially created for the Swiss city of stars, making more than just children's eyes sparkle. The huge, festively decorated Christmas tree in front of the cathedral's baroque towers is another highlight.

The Christmas market takes place under the starry sky of St. Gallen every day during Advent. The offerings are varied: from homemade hats to fragrant candles and hot mulled wine, everything is on offer. A varied program of musicians, choirs and artistic performances is part of the Christmas season under the starry sky.

In addition to the Christmas market, artists present their home-made Christmas creations on two Advent Saturdays at the Christkindlimarkt on Gallusplatz.

If you would like to hear stories and anecdotes about the city of stars, join the "Christmas tour in the city of stars", which is offered in the run-up to Christmas.

More information: Christmas in St. Gallen [https://sternenstadt.ch/]

data.name: Botanical Gardens, St.Gallen
data.abstract: Around 8,000 plant species from all over the world thrive on the two hectares of the Botanical Gardens at Stephanshorn, St. Gallen. Special features include the Tropical House, with its rainforest plants, succulents and orchids, and the architecturally remarkable Alpine House.
data.description:
The widely diverse plants are divided into around 20 different categories. Groupings include geographical zones (Europe, America, Asia), academic subject areas (biology, genetics, systems), species with human uses (agricultural, poisonous and medicinal plants), and a number of individual plant sections such as the maple grove, the iris corner and the fern dell.

The Alpine House is not just an architectural jewel: it boasts a wide variety of exceptional botanical specimens, and the range on display is constantly rotated. Other highlights of the St. Gallen Botanical Gardens include a house devoted to carnivorous plants and another to lithops or “living stones” . The nutrient-poor (but species-rich) grassland area is home to over a hundred native meadowland species. 

Visitors can benefit from the regular events, exhibitions and guided tours to expand their knowledge of the world's treasury of plants, or simply seek out and enjoy a beautiful spot in this idyllic garden.

data.name: University of St.Gallen
data.description:
On account of its architectural uniqueness, which is essentially characterized by art, the University is famous far beyond the national borders. The University is regarded as a complete work of art based architectural achievements and fine arts.



EXPERIENCE THE UNIVERSITY OF ST.GALLEN (HSG)

Have you always wanted to know more about the HSG?
Visit us on campus during a public tour of the main building and library. You will quickly see that the University of St.Gallen is more than just a place for learning and science as you find out more about its vision, facts and history. Explore the buildings and discover impressive works of art. The presentation of art at our university is far removed from boring museum exhibits. Instead, artwork is integrated into the architecture and the students' daily lives here. Almost all of the art was created by the artists specifically for the spot where it is now displayed and not just moved there afterwards.

data.name: Photo Spot St. Gallen
data.abstract: The three artificial water basins ‘Drei Weieren’ were created in 1610 to secure the water supply for the textile bleaching industry as well as the fire brigades. Today they are a water park, an oasis of serenity and a wonderful recreation area. Located just a few minutes from the Grand Tour, the ponds invite visitors to swim, take a stroll or picnic in the summers, and ice-skate in cold winters. The fact that Drei Weieren are amongst Switzerland’s most beautiful natural swimming pools is also due to the magnificent view of Lake Constance, the city of St. Gallen and the Abbey Cathedral which has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1983.

data.name: Swiss Casino St.Gallen
data.abstract: Soak up this fun atmosphere full of glitz and glamour.
data.description:
Try your luck in this unique setting with its numerous gaming tables and 190 slot machines, plus a bar to relax in. 
The Swiss Casino St.Gallen is noted for its modernity and spaciousness and provides the Lake Constance region with a gaming experience in an unusual and authentic atmosphere. 

Dress Code: Well-groomed attire, shirt with collar for the gentlemen. (A limited number of jackets is available on loan)

data.name: Textile trail St. Gallen
data.abstract: Eastern Switzerland is internationally recognised for its textile tradition and for its outstanding expertise in this industry. A trail through the city of St. Gallen will teach you lots of interesting facts about Eastern Switzerland's textile industry.
data.description:
The five-kilometre St. Gallen textile trail will take you to standout buildings for the textile industry in the heart of the city. There are all manner of things to learn about the history and architecture of the buildings, as well as how they are used today.

The trail takes between one and two hours, depending on your pace and how long you like to stop off at each building for. QR codes at the individual stop-off points reveal interesting facts about the buildings and the textile legacy in St. Gallen.

data.name: Stiftsbibliothek (Abbey Library) St. Gallen
data.abstract: St. Gall's Abbey Library is one of the oldest and most beautiful in the world. The origins of the library date back to the 8th century, and many of its 160,000 priceless texts are nearly that old.
data.description: On display are the 8th-century bill of sale for the abbey property; a Gospel of John ca 800 AD; Changing exhibitions show handwritten and illuminated texts, including Bibles, liturgical works, prayer books and biographies of saints from as early as the 9th 8th century AD; and works depicting the daily lives of resident monks, which provide insight into abbey life from the 9th century through the Middle Ages. Some early works are written in Irish, evidence of the monastery's Irish roots (hence the name, "St. Gall"). The elaborate, rococo library was constructed between 1758-67 and is worth admiration in its own right, with its magnificent burnished woodwork, undulating balconies and ceiling frescoes.

data.name: Crime scene in St. Gallen
data.abstract: On this guided tour, you’ll head off together in search of criminals and uncover their illegal wheeling and dealing in the city of St. Gallen.
data.description: Time for eerily exciting stories: Join us on a search for clues through the city centre of St.Gallen! We uncover criminal machinations in the city of St.Gallen, accompany the counterfeiters, thieves and murderers to the place of judgement and bring them to justice.

data.name: Foxtrail – fun in St. Gallen
data.abstract: The fox takes chasers on four different trails across St. Gallen. The fox hides away in the “city of a thousand stairs”, as intricate as a piece of St. Gallen embroidery. Be careful not to lose the scent at the train station already.
data.description: The fox has laid its trails. Secret messages, hidden clues and many tricky and perplexing challenges show you the way from one stop to the next. You are out on the trail by yourself and never know what’s waiting in store for you – even people familiar with the region are bound to discover new things. The Foxtrail takes you through towns and countryside on foot and using various means of transport. The trails last between 1.5 and 4.5 hours. All you’ll need is good shoes and a mobile phone per group in case you need to call the hotline. Pricing depends on your age and the length of the trail. Simply book online through the website, print the starting instructions and enjoy solving the puzzles!

data.name: Christmas tour of St. Gallen
data.abstract: For lovers of the reflective Advent season, St.Gallen is one of the most beautiful "Christmas treats" of all. 700 stars shine down on the romantic Old Town. The streets are lined with the festively decorated stalls for the Christmas and Christchindli Market.
data.description:
While on this Christmas tour through the St.Gallen Old Town and the Abbey District, you will hear anecdotes and background information about the Christmas period in St.Gallen. 

After these exciting tours through the City of St. Gall, visitors can warm up with a hot drink and sample delicious Christmas cookies.

data.name: Public guided tours of St.Gallen
data.abstract: The best way for individual guests and locals to discover this UNESCO World Heritage city.
data.description: This guided walking tour for individual guests includes a visit to the Abbey Library and the Textile Museum. The specialist, multilingual guides share fascinating stories about St.Gallen, and episodes and anecdotes from the past - thus providing a comprehensive impression of the glorious past to the present day.

data.name: Group tours at the open art Museum
data.abstract: St. Gallen has so much to offer when it comes to museums. Attractive, internationally renowned exhibitions and countless historic collections make for a diverse museum landscape. The open art Museum is particularly worth a visit.
data.description:
The open art Museum in St. Gallen is the only museum for art brut in the German-speaking region. It captures visitors' imaginations with its diverse offering and fascinating content. The museum's collection is devoted to art in the fields of art brut, outsider art and naive art. It boasts an impressive collection, comprising over 8,000 works of art by more than 180 artists.

As part of regular group tours, the museum's art education specialists will show you around the latest exhibition. Your guide is included in the normal entry fee.

data.name: Appenzeller Aussichtsroute
data.abstract: The scenic Appenzell route leads from Heiden through the hilly Appenzell landscapes to the Gallus town of St. Gallen – passing known and lesser known points of interest on the way.
data.description:
Start of tour:Heiden End of tour:St.Gallen Number of stages:1Length:39 km Asphalted:39 km Natural surface:0 km Demanding physical fitness:mittel Difference in altitude:↑ 820 m
↓ 950 m 
Discover the diversity of Appenzellerland by bicycle or electrobike – including sweeping views over Lake Constance from Heiden! From the first vantage point, take in the vistas of the St. Galler Rheintal and Alpstein. Roaming over hills and dales, the tour reveals all the various facets of this lovely region situated between Lake Constance and Säntis.

There is also a great deal to discover on the route in addition to the magnificent panorama and exceptional scenic attractions. At the Pestalozzi childrens' village in Trogen, gain an insight into the life experienced by more than 220,000 kids and teenagers from all over the world that are supported each year by the Pestalozzi Foundation. In Stein, see how the famous Appenzeller cheese is made. Talking of cheese: numerous restaurants along the way will delight in boosting your energy levels with tasty regional specialities.

At the end of the tour, the 99 meter-high «Ganggelibrugg»- and thus Europe's highest foot-bridge - lies at the threshold to St. Gallen. And on arriving in this Gallus town a stroll through the Old Town with its famous cloister district is well worth the time.

data.name: Appenzell Railways
data.abstract: The Appenzell Railways connect the main towns of this charming area, such as St. Gallen with its Abbey Library, Appenzell with its Tudor-style houses, more than a thousand-year-old Herisau and Gossau, dominated by its 13th century castle Oberberg.
data.description:
Go on a tour of beautiful Appenzellerland and discover its hilly landscape, lush green meadows and farmhouses. The Appenzell Railways (AB) network links the major towns and villages.

It’s also well worth visiting Appenzell itself to admire the traditional Appenzell houses lining the ever-popular main street. If you have a bit more time, we recommend heading up to Säntis (2,502 metres above sea level) or one of the other stunning mountains in the Alpstein massif. Railway geeks will also love the three cogwheel sections. The Discovery Tour is a chance to enjoy two nostalgic cogwheel trains, as well as the Joke Trail (Witzweg) and a gentle boat trip.

Suggested excursions:
Gossau – Appenzell – Wasserauen
- Great choice of packages – Murder on the Railway, Brunch Ride, Fondue Rides, Quöllfrisch Express and many more.
- Alpstein – take a trip up one of the most stunning mountains in Eastern Switzerland
- Various attractions in Appenzell
- Wasserauen Museum – the history of Appenzell Railways
- E-bike hire at Appenzell train station

Trogen – St. Gallen – Appenzell
- Amazing views of the town of St. Gallen from the train
- Several great hiking trails with train connections to Trogen, St. Gallen and Appenzell

Rorschach – Heiden/Rheineck – Walzenhausen
- Discovery Tour – by cable car, postbus and boat through the Appenzell Vorderland region
- Open carriages – feel the summer sun on your face (Rorschach – Heiden)

Altstätten – Gais
- Bike carriers – outdoor fun on sunny summer days
- Open carriages – feel the summer sun on your face
- Tobogganing fun – in winter on the Stoss – Altstätten toboggan run

Timetable
Details of all Appenzell Railways connections can be found here [https://appenzellerbahnen.ch/de/reiseinformationen/fahrplan.html].

Tickets
Free travel with the Swiss Pass, Swiss Flexi Pass and Swiss Youth Pass
50% discount with the Swiss Half Fare Card, from CHF 20 with the OSTWIND 9:00 am day pass

Offers
Book now [https://appenzellerbahnen.ch/de/erlebnisangebote.html]

Reservations
Planning a group or class trip with Appenzell Railways? Please register the group in advance with Appenzell station by calling 071 788 50 50.

data.name: Treetop path Neckertal
data.abstract: In Mogelsberg in the Toggenburg holiday region near St. Gallen, the first treetop path in Switzerland was opened in May 2018. The 500-metre disabled-accessible path gently winds from the forest floor into the treetops – a unique nature experience where visitors are at eye level with the flora and fauna.
data.description:
Around 40 stops invite you to discover the trees, listen to the sounds of the forest, observe the woodland animals or simply relax. The viewing platform extends up over 50 metres from the ground. From here, visitors can enjoy a sweeping view of the entire Neckertal valley as far as Toggenburger Churfirsten and Appenzellerland. 

If you're craving a light snack, cold and warm dishes are offered in the self-service bistro. Around the treetop path, there are also facilities for active recreation and relaxation. A fitness trail, a log cabin, a forest adventure trail, BBQ areas, idyllic rest areas, a children’s playground and a dreamy natural pond. 

Treetop path Neckertal offers wheelchair-friendly parking, with further parking spaces just a 15 to 30-minute walk away. For visitors arriving by public transport, a 40-minute walk leads directly from Mogelsberg train station to Steinwäldli.

data.name: Peter and Paul wildlife park
data.abstract: Ibex, chamois, lynx, wildcat, deer and wild boar are among the native Swiss animals at the Peter and Paul wildlife park on the scenic St. Gallen-Rotmonten hilltop.
data.description:
Set in a typical Prealpine landscape, this popular venue with its new information centre offers a fascinating outing at any time of year – along with glorious views and delicious regional specialities at the Peter and Paul restaurant. Admission is free. 

The wildlife park building is also well worth a visit. Primarily intended for schools and interested groups, it houses illustrative material about the animals living in the park. Such items as horns, antlers, hides and pictures of tracks can be touched. Animal sounds and short film sequences can be called up on the large touch screen.

data.name: Erststockbeizli
data.abstract: The city of St.Gallen is known for its legendary “Erststockbeizli”, characteristic, traditional restaurants and wine taverns located on the first floors of the historic timber-framed houses of the old town.
data.description:
The ground on which the city was built in the Middle Ages was wet and swampy, so that social activities did not take place on the damp, musty ground floor, but on the first floor. Social meeting places such as pubs and taverns were moved to where it was much brighter. The gothic timber beams are still preserved in some Erststockbeizli. Low ceilings and wood-panelled walls contribute to the cosy atmosphere in these rooms. From this elevated position, restaurant goers can watch the hustle and bustle on the streets and squares below. Dinner in an Erststockbeizli is a must when visiting the city of St.Gallen.

Traditional Erststockbeizli restaurants include:

 * Genussmanufaktur Neubad: [https://www.restaurantneubad.ch/]this traditional Erststockbeizli offers a culinary journey in a class of its own. Built around 1550, these historic walls house a restaurant where unconventional interpretations of Erststockbeizli dishes can be expected. Immerse yourself in the world of so-called gourmet plates that reject the classic distinction between starters and main courses. Here, all the plates are the same size so that you can try as many different things as possible and send your taste buds on a voyage of discovery. Welcome to a unique culinary experience where tradition and creativity come together in every bite.
 * Weinstube zum Bäumli: [https://www.weinstube-baeumli.ch/] This wine tavern is located in the heart of an enchanting timber-framed house that is over 600 years old. Here, you are not only invited to enjoy exquisite wines in an historic setting, but also to celebrate culinary delights. Discover unusual delicacies, such as delicious tripe in a tantalising white wine sauce or let your senses be enchanted by classics such as calf liver with rösti or St.Gallen bratwurst.
 * Wirtschaft zur alten Post: [https://apost.ch/]welcome to a restaurant that embodies a rustic, cosy atmosphere in a unique way. This lovingly restored house dating back to 1552 is the setting for a perfect symbiosis of nostalgia and contemporary culinary delights. The bratwurst from the lava stone grill, accompanied by a crispy rösti is recommended as a culinary masterpiece and is an absolute highlight.
 * Zum goldenen Schäfli: [https://www.zumgoldenenschaeflisg.ch/]the cosy restaurant “Zum Goldenen Schäfli” is probably the best-known example of a classic Erststockbeizli. It is located in a former butchers’ guildhall in the centre of the historic old town of St.Gallen. Over 500 years old, this building is the last of its kind in St.Gallen and has a fascinating history. The special trademark of the Erststockbeizli is that everything here is a little off-centre: The floors, the gothic wooden ceiling, the level in the wine glass – and the person at the top of the table sits a good 20 centimetres higher than the person at the bottom. The unique feature of this Erststockbeizli lies in its charming imbalance: The floors tilt slightly, just like the gothic wooden ceiling and the level in the wine glass – and the person at the top of the table sits a good 20 centimetres higher than the person at the far end. Here, history is not only tasted, it is experienced.

You will find an overview of all of the region’s culinary highlights here [https://shop.st.gallen-bodensee.ch/de/pages/genuss-und-kulinarik?_gl=1%2a6994fi%2a_ga%2aMTM0MzYxNjc5OC4xNzA0MjY1ODkz%2a_ga_0Y52PB54YH%2aMTcwNDM3NzE0Ny4xMi4xLjE3MDQzODA0MTEuMjguMC4w&_ga=2.4959477.712355876.1704265893-1343616798.1704265893].

data.name: Toggenburger Höhenweg
data.abstract: The Toggenburger Höhenweg presents hikers with one of the most beautiful but also one of the most challenging hiking routes in the St. Gallen countryside. Breathtaking and incomparable views constantly draw your gaze down into the lush green Thurtal valley.
data.description:
Start of tour:Wildhaus End of tour:Will SG Number of stages:6Length:87 km Difficulty:mediumCondition:difficult Difference in altitude:↑ 4600 m
↓ 5100 m 
The scenic Toggenburger Höhenweg runs parallel to the Thurweg. Unlike the Thurweg, which follows alongside the River Thur on the valley floor, the Höhenweg leads at a height along the south/west side of the Toggenburg valley. Starting point is Wildhaus, birthplace of reformer Huldrych Zwingli and home of four-times Olympic champion Simon Ammann (Unterwasser). 

The Höhenweg repeatedly has links into the valley, to typical Toggenburg villages with public transport connections. Simple, hospitable mountain huts make it possible to stay overnight at a lofty height. This is rewarding mainly because of the wonderful views of the Churfirsten mountains at an early or late hour. En route, you'll be constantly enthralled by the extensive views over the Glarus Alps and the Walensee and Zürichsee lakes into Toggenburg as far as the Bodensee (Lake Constance). 

Towards its end, the Höhenweg leaves the rather challenging mountain trail and finishes amidst gently rolling hills in the town of Wil, known as the gateway to Toggenburg.

data.name: City Park
data.abstract: Originally a private landscape garden, the City Park is today the largest contiguous green space in the St. Gallen inner city area. With its lawned areas under beautiful old trees, it is the epitome of a peaceful oasis in the middle of the hustle and bustle of the city. It is surrounded by Theater St. Gallen, the Museum of Art, and the Historical and Folklore Museum.
data.description:
It was previously the garden for house number 25 on Rorschacher Strasse. In 1880, the park underwent a major transformation when the museum was built. On the east side of the museum, the botanical garden was created with its austere basic forms, and this was later moved to the east side of the city. 
The aviary association constructed an octagonal enclosure in the middle of the park. Currently, the city park serves as an attractive green space for the adjoining Theater St. Gallen.

data.name: Gall Trail
data.abstract: Hikers on the Gall Trail follow in the footsteps of the itinerant Irish monk Gall, who, in 612, travelled from Arbon to St.Gallen and established his hermit's cell in the Mülenen Gorge.
data.description:
One hundred years later, an abbey was built on the site of this small cell – an abbey that became known as the “writing room of Europe” in the Middle Ages and one of the most important cultural centers of the West. The city of St. Gallen came into being around the abbey. 

Route: 
Arbon – Steinach – St.Gallen

data.name: Collegiate Library
data.abstract: The St. Gallen Collegiate Library is one of the oldest libraries in the world. It is the heart of the abbey district and immerses you in history with its large baroque hall and valuable manuscripts.
data.description:
The St. Gallen Collegiate Library is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the oldest libraries in the world. It contains around 170,000 volumes, including 2,100 valuable manuscripts, many of which are over 1,000 years old. The works offer fascinating insights into the monastic culture of St. Gallen.

The baroque hall is an authentic eye-catcher and is one of the most beautiful library rooms in Switzerland. Visitors can marvel at rare manuscripts and special pieces in changing exhibitions. A special highlight is the 2,700-year-old Egyptian mummy Schepenese.

data.name: New exhibition space for the Plan of St. Gall
data.abstract: The entire Convent of St. Gall has been a UNESCO World Heritage site since 1983. The baroque cathedral with its twin-tower façade is the emblematic landmark of the historic city of St. Gallen and one of the last monumental monastic constructions of the Baroque. The abbey library – one of the oldest and most beautiful in the world – is at the heart of the Abbey District.
data.description:
From spring 2018, another two attractions will add to the offerings in the Abbey District: the renovated vaulted cellar in the abbey library telling the story of the St. Gallen cathedral, and an interactive exhibition room with the Plan of St. Gall. The undoubted highlight of this exhibition is seeing the original plan of the St. Gall from the 9th century.

More information [https://st.gallen-bodensee.ch/de/nachrichten-stories/zwei-neue-ausstellungssaele-im-stiftsbezirk-st-gallen-und-eine-neue-website.html]

data.name: Coachman & Vintner – a successful team
data.abstract: The visitor can look forward to a wine tasting and a coach ride through the idyllic landscape of St. Gallen.
data.description:
During a romantic horse-drawn carriage ride, you will have the opportunity to enjoy the magnificent landscape of Thal, situated between Lake Constance and Rebberg. After the ride, an apéritif in the vineyard or wine cellar of a Buechberger vintner is in order. 

 * May to August
 * Route as discussed with the coachman 
 * Hourly stop for wine tasting



Up to 10 persons 700 CHF 
Each additional person 70 CHF

data.name: Food for thought
data.abstract: A matter of taste. There is no such thing as a single Swiss cuisine. As you travel through Switzerland you’ll find Berner Rösti, buttery home-fried potatoes in Bern; Malakoff cheese fritters in Canton Vaud; and cornmeal specialities and freshly caught perch from Lake Constance in Canton St. Gallen. The Valais is famous for its raclette, melted mountain cheese served with steamed new potatoes and pickles; Graubünden for its Capuns, tender dumplings wrapped in Swiss chard leaves; Zürich for its Geschnetzeltes, creamy shredded veal; and Ticino for its luganighe sausages and fabulous risotto. Switzerland has an incredible number of traditional regional dishes – a world record in proportion to its size.
data.description:
FLAVOURS OF THE MARKET
Every city and large village holds a market once or twice a week, with the freshest foods from farmers, butchers, bakers and cheese makers. The markets in Bellinzona [http://www.bellinzonaturismo.ch/framework/Desktopdefault.aspx?menu_index=31&menu_id=381] , Chur [http://www.churtourismus.ch], Basel [http://www.basel.com/en.cfm/baselinfo/baselbilder/offer-BaselInfoBT-Speziell-236445.html] and Solothurn [http://www.mysolothurn.com/markte?opt=viewObj&wid=157&objId=318] are particularly enticing. 

TRADITIONAL FOOD AT THE SWISS OPEN-AIR MUSEUM
This museum in Ballenberg [http://www.ballenberg.ch] near Brienz works to keep history alive – and that includes the history of food. From spring to autumn, you can watch the butcher, the baker, the cheese maker and the chocolate maker at work. It’s enough to make your mouth water… 

A DELICIOUS HIKE
The high path between Chasseral and Frinvilliers near Biel offers not only spectacular views, but also the chance to visit a dozen or so métairies along the way: alpine huts where regional specialities such as cheese, Rösti and ham are served. 

DIRECT FROM THE LAND
Nearly all the fruits, vegetables, jams, wines, cheeses, and sausages from the canton of Vaud can be found in a single shop, La Ferme vaudoise [http://www.lafermeyverdon.ch] in Yverdon-les-Bains. 


LADLE IN HAND
You can learn some of the secrets of Swiss cooking by enrolling in a cookery course. These take place all over the country, from Geneva to the Engadine, and from Schaffhausen to Ticino. More experienced cooks may choose to study with one of Switzerland’s superchefs: Chef of the Year 2007 Markus Neff at the Hotel Fletschhorn [http://www.fletschhorn.ch] in Saas-Fee, Vreni Giger at the Restaurant Jägerhof [http://www.jaegerhof.ch] in St. Gallen, Kurt Röösli at the Hotel Waldhaus [http://www.waldhaus-sils.ch] in Sils- Maria, Urs Gschwend at the Hotel Giardino [http://www.giardino.ch/?lang=eng] in Ascona, or Irene Dörig at Irene’s Cuisine [http://www.irenes-cuisine.ch] in Friedlisberg near Zürich.

data.name: Mülenen Gorge
data.abstract: The Mülenen Gorge is a narrow ravine south of the old town of St.Gallen. At the lower end of the valley - so the story goes – Saint Gall stumbled and fell among thorns.
data.description:
This he saw as a divine sign and he built his hermit's cell here. This later developed into the monastery of St.Gallen from which the city of St.Gallen grew centuries later. 
This is now the location of the Valley Station for the Mühleggbahn, a cogwheel train that takes you up to St.Georgen.

data.name: Hoher Kasten – Top of Appenzell
data.abstract: The views from the platform between Appenzell country and the St. Gallen Rhine Valley are striking, as is the ridge towards Kreuzberge. Since 1964, the cable car from Brülisau (bus from Weissbad) has run directly to the summit. A revolving restaurant with a sun terrace also stands on the extended platform as well as a circular trail around the summit which allows spectacular panoramic views over six countries.
data.description:
Informative panorama boards and free telescopes with integrated peak identification explain the wider surroundings. Take a stroll or guided tour through the summit's Alpine garden and discover more than 300 species of Alpstein plants. A wheelchair-friendly panoramic trail with attractive viewing spots now leads in a large arc around the restaurant. 

The newly created geologic hike also commences on the Hoher Kasten, explaining the shaping, folds and fractures of the rocky terrain on a total 17 boards. Gondola-style rail leads from Stauberenkanzel to the Rhine Valley – with the geological path leading further afar, via Saxerlücke to the Fählensee lake (total 3 hours 30 min).

INFORMATION
Altitude: 1794m 
Accessibility: 
Bus from Weissbad (Appenzell) to the Brülisau valley station, cable car to the Hoher Kasten 
View: Alpstein (Säntis), Appenzell, Rhine Valley 
Attractions: Over 400 km of alpine hiking trails, all in top condition, Geological Panorama Hiking Trail, summit hike on Europa Rundweg Circular Trail and alpine garden
Culinary aspects: Revolving restaurant and sun terrace, regional specialities, breakfast buffets on weekends 
Overnight stays: no
Groups: Revolving restaurant: 84, maximum 98 seats, middle floor with separate halls for 70 and 80, max 150 guests. Seminar room with 20 places 
Winter: Cable car and restaurant open all year round from April until end of February, March ceased due to maintance reasons; no winter sports operations. 
Special comments: Exclusive Fullmoon dinner and special evenings rides
Please note:Buy your tickets on arrival at the station or via « Hoher Kasten » App.


RESTAURANT RESERVATIONS
Phone +41 71 799 11 17 or drehrestaurant@hoherkasten.ch [drehrestaurant@hoherkasten.ch ]


MOUNTAIN DAY TRIPS
Buy your reduced rate mountain rail ascent return tickets now

Timetable and tickets [https://www.sbb.ch/en/buying/pages/fahrplan/fahrplan.xhtml?&nach=bruelisau]

data.name: Akris
data.abstract: The high fashion Akris label was established in 1922 in St.Gallen. Over the last 30 years, Albert Kriemler has transformed this fashion label into a luxury label.
data.description: These collections, with their marvelous fabric creations and equally sophisticated and timeless styles, are extremely impressive. This is stylish, elegant fashion that perfectly complements the personality of each woman. With any luck, you will find a bargain somewhere in the in-house outlet in St. Gallen. The range includes elegant jackets, pants, blouses, dresses, bags and much more.

data.name: Historical Points
data.abstract: Where spirituality and beauty unite. St.Gallen has a very special landmark: its sublime cathedral. It forms, with the world famous Abbey Library, a historic ensemble that is unrivalled, and which was declared UNESCO World Heritage in 1983. The famous Abbey Library sports the most beautiful secular Rococo interior in Switzerland. Dubbed a “pharmacy for the soul”, it is home to 170.000 books as well as 2.000 priceless medieval manuscripts.
data.description:
HIGHLIGHTS IN ST. GALLEN
Religious sites [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites.html?start=26]
Overnight at a monestary [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html]
Christmas Markets [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/event_calendar/event_results.cfm?f2=stxmas] 
HISTORY OF ST. GALLEN
The city of St.Gallen was founded by the Irish monk Gallus in 612. In search of a suitable place for his hermit's cell, he stumbled and fell into a bush of thorns somewhere in a wild, narrow high-lying valley of what is now St.Gallen. He took that and his close encounter with a bear to be signs sent to him by God and decided to stay. One hundred years later, the very place where Gallus set up his hermitage became the site of an abbey which was to become the "writing room of Europe" in the Middle Ages and one of the most important cultural centres of the Occident. The town that gradually grew up around that abbey is St.Gallen. 

St.Gallen's history, the splendour of its abbey and the monuments that testify to civic pride and a prosperous economy in the Middle Ages, are evident at every turn in St.Gallen. The abbey district with its magnificent baroque cathedral forms a unique historical ensemble, which was designated a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in the year 1983. Visitors to the abbey's rococo library can admire 170,000 medieval books and 2000 original manuscripts in changing temporary exhibitions. 

TEXTILES IN ST. GALLEN
The production of textiles played a significant role in St.Gallen as early as the Middle Ages. For centuries, cloth from St.Gallen was a lucrative export article, appreciated throughout Europe for its quality. During the industrial revolution in the 19th century, it was embroidery and fine lace that accounted for St.Gallen's fame. The textile museum provides a fascinating account of the town's "textile" history.

ST. GALLEN AND VICINITY 
The city’s central location in the Lake Constance region makes it an ideal base for a host of excursions to Lake Constance or to the mountains of the Appenzellerland for example to the mount Säntis (2,501 m/8,205 f) the most famous mountain in Eastern Switzerland. 

The rural St.Gallen area is as well a marvellous hiking and biking region, with lake and mountain panoramas always in view.

In 2012 St.Gallen will celebrate its 1400 year anniversary with various events.
THE INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE REFORMATION
This museum is a must-see for religious visitors that come to Geneva, Switzerland. It begins with an emphasis on the Bible and includes some of the oldest French and English Bibles. Unique objects, manuscripts, rare books, engravings and paintings illustrate the close ties of Geneva and John Calvin to the Reformation.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites/musee-international-de-la-reforme-international-museum-of-the-reformation-genf.html]
OVERNIGHT IN A MONASTERY
Experience how it is to live in a monastery and overnight in one of the various abbeys and monasteries in Switzerland that offer simple accommodation. Some even offer their own mountain hut refuge to rent, like the convent of St.John in Muestair
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html?all]
THE PILGRIMAGE WAY OF ST. JAMES ALONG SWITZERLAND’S BREATHTAKING MOUNTAIN SCENERY.
Walk or cycle on St. James' footsteps, following his ways through the breathtaking mountain scenery of Switzerland to Santiago de Compostela. Take your time to visit some of the traditional pilgrims' stations.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/home/summervacations/excursion-summer/summer-mountain-tips/the-way-itself-is-the-goal.html]
CHRISTMAS MARKETS.
The Christmas season will soon be here again.. as well as the traditional Christmas markets in Switzerland. Montreux is home to the largest one, Bremgarten (Aargau) to one of the biggest ones in terms of vendors. The highest one can be visited on Mt. Pilatus. Others can be found in Huttwil (Bern), Zürich or Basel. 
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/service-updates/events.html?strubrik=2161]

data.name: House of Wine in the Rhine Valley
data.abstract: The St. Gallen Rhine Valley is one of the most beautiful hiking regions and holiday resorts in Switzerland. Its dreamlike valley location between Lake Constance, Sargans and Altenrhein attracts not only hikers and connoisseurs, but also wine lovers.
data.description:
As of October 2018, the House of Wine in Berneck is a new hub for products from regional winegrowers. It is open to the public and holds tastings of regional wine and other local products. This can be combined with an expert guided tour of the Rhine Valley wine region. Wine lovers can explore the history of viticulture here along a wine trail or learn interesting facts about winemaking in the past as well as how it is today on a guided tour of the vineyard and wine cellar.

For spur-of-the-moment visits, the House of Wine is open from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. every Saturday.

Getting there: By train from St. Gallen to Heerbrugg, and then by bus to the “Berneck, Rathaus” stop.

More information [https://hausdesweins-sg.ch/]

data.name: A piece of textile history
data.abstract: Textile manufacturing has shaped St. Gallen for centuries. The ambition, foresight and creativity of export merchants led the city to a leading position in both the linen trade and the embroidery industry. The magnificent buildings and opulent façades, as well as the collection of the Textile Museum, bear witness to this.
data.description: Learn about the history of the textile industry in St. Gallen on a guided tour at the world famous Jakob Schlaepfer embroidery boutique. It exports St.Gallen embroidery worldwide and supplies Haute Couture fashion houses.

price.description: Textile Museum ticket prices: Individuals: CHF 12 per person Groups of 10 or more: CHF 9 per person Surcharges: Sunday and public holiday surcharge: CHF 20 Evening tour from 8 p.m.: CHF 20 Express bookings (less than two working days in advance): CHF 40

data.name: Thurbo Seelinie (lake line)
data.abstract: The railway line between St. Gallen, Stein am Rhein and Schaffhausen runs along a unique lake and river landscape. Hop off and on wherever you like – “Thurbo” trains operate at half-hour intervals.
data.description:
The voyage on the “Thurbo” along Lake Constance and the Rhine leads you through the Cantons of St. Gallen, Thurgau and Schaffhausen. The many villages with picturesque historic old towns along the route invite visitors to exploration tours. Are you interested in culture? Visit one of the many museums along the “lake line”. Those who appreciate the good things in life take a seat in a cosy restaurant and savour the local specialities. 

Peace, quiet and leisureliness are quite important during this travel experience. Guests are in no hurry: having got off the train, the next one is never more than 30 minutes away. The lake line is a railway and nature treat for everyone. Insider tip: For the best view of the scenery from the train seat, choose the side of the train where the windows face the lake and river!

FACTS
Route: St. Gallen – Stein am Rhein – Schaffhausen and vice-versa Distance: 86 km Duration: 1 h 52 min EXCURSION TIPS
 * Historic old towns ofSchaffhausen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/schaffhausen/], Diessenhofen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/diessenhofen/], Stein am Rhein [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/stein-am-rhein/], Steckborn [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/steckborn/], Berlingen, Ermatingen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/ermatingen/], Gottlieben, Arbon [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/arbon/]and Rorschach [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/rorschach/].
 * Diverse offer of museums, e.g. Museum zu Allerheiligen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/museum-zur-allerheiligen/]in Schaffhausen, Napoleon Museum [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/arenenberg-castle-and-the-napoleonic-museum/]in Salenstein, Museum of History and Oldtimer Museum in Arbon.
 * Historic town ofSt. Gallen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/st-gallen/]with theAbbey Library [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/st-gallen-abbey-district/](part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site) with more than 170,000 books and scripts.
 * Part of the lake line can be travelled on a lake boat [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/swiss-navigation-company-untersee-am-rhein/]in both directions – e.g. between Stein am Rhein and Schaffhausen.

FOOD & BEVERAGES
There is no catering on the train.

TIMETABLE
Trains depart between 5am and 11pm at 30-minute intervals in both directions
To the timetable [https://www.sbb.ch/de]

TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book Swiss Travel System tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATION
It is not possible to make a reservation on this line.

data.name: Mühleggbahn
data.abstract: The Mühleggbahn connects the old town of St. Gallen with the Drei Weiern and St. Georgen recreation area. The historic railway, which has been in operation since 1893, now runs fully automatically and offers quick access to nature.
data.description:
The Mühleggbahn connects the old town of St. Gallen with the popular Drei Weiern recreational area and the St. Georgen district. In just a few minutes, you can reach the idyllic ponds, which are perfect for walking, swimming or simply relaxing. The railway runs fully automatically and at the touch of a button, so you can travel flexibly and comfortably. A special highlight: the valley station has been designed with the word “Bangor” and is a reminder of the city's roots.

 The walk around the «Drei Weieren» takes about 30 to 45 minutes. The additional tour round the Notkersegg Nunnery takes about 15 to 20 minutes.

data.name: Monastery Square
data.abstract: Within the abbey complex just north of the Abbey Cathedral is Monastery Square, a large, open, grassy area.
data.description: The space frequently hosts open-air concerts, theatrical productions and carnivals, often of a religious nature. Contact St. Gallen- Bodensee Tourism for a calendar of events.

data.name: Through the Rorschach region by e-bike
data.abstract: This diverse region by Lake Constance is best explored by e-bike. The route takes you through idyllic small towns, picturesque landscapes and a wonderful nature reserve.
data.description: The tour starts in the harbour town of Rorschach and takes you past Würth Haus Rorschach and all the way to St. Gallen–Altenrhein Airport. Then it's along the Alter Rhein and through the Altenrhein nature reserve to the village of Thal. A leisurely stage through the vineyards follows next, before attempting the ascent up the Rorschacherberg. From the top of the Rorschacherberg, impressive views of Lake Constance are a treat for nature lovers. Back on the shore of Lake Constance, take in the town of Rorschach's two landmarks: the bathing hut and the former granary. The e-bike tour is a fantastic experience for lovers of nature and culture, and shows the region by Lake Constance in an entirely new light.

data.name: Hidden treasures
data.abstract: Change your perspective, take a closer look, discover hidden secrets and hear tales of the city’s past.
data.description:
The treasure tour is a truly special way to see the city and learning delightful details about St. Gallen, with many interesting, funny and thought-provoking stories told along the way. This will appeal not only to those who know the city of St. Gallen well, but also those who want to discover an extraordinary side to the city.

More information [https://st.gallen-bodensee.ch/de/erlebnisse/fuehrungen/verborgene-schaetze.html]

data.name: Vadian Monument
data.abstract: Since 1904, a monumental statue of Joachim von Watt (1484-1551) known as Vadian has stood on the location of the former City Hall that was demolished in 1877.
data.description: This St.Gallen reformer, mayor, doctor and historian is the only person in St. Gallen honoured with a statue that is larger than life.

data.name: St. Laurenzen Kirche (St. Lawrence Church)
data.abstract: The tower of the St. Lawrence Church affords a beautiful view of the Old Town and the Abbey Precinct.
data.description:
Besides the Cathedral, this is the city's most important church. The present building dates back to the 15th century, but it was entirely reconstructed from 1850 to 1854 and now is a basilica in neo-Gothic style. After climbing the tower, you will have a wonderful view over the roofs of St.Gallen.



TOWER TOURS:
Mon - Sat usually 9.30 - 11.30 am and 2.00 - 4.00 pm
Groups and school classes by appointment only, Tel. 071 222 67 92
The tower remains closed during the winter.

data.name: Fountains and scuptures
data.description: City Park with "Magician's'Fountain," built by Max Oertli. On the opposite side is "The Trunk" by Richard Sierra. Art works by Roman Signer, such as the fountain "The Barrel", the Upper Moat, sculpture around the University of St.Gallen, among others.

data.name: St.Galler Festspiele
data.abstract: Every year at the end of June, the monastery courtyard in the Abbey District is transformed into an opera setting.
data.description:
Colossal stage sets and amazing technical feats coupled with the unique backdrop of the magnificent baroque cathedral make the St. Gallen Festival a must for all who love opera and culture.

More information [http://www.stgaller-festspiele.ch/de/]

data.name: Mountain railway trip on the Pizol
data.abstract: Two gondola railways make their way up from Bad Ragaz or Wangs to the edge of the forest, from where you enjoy far-reaching views over the Rhine Valley to Lake Constance – and chairlifts carrying you to the Pizol ridge if you wish to venture further afield.
data.description:
The five lakes hike from the mountain station and back to Alp Gaffia notably attracts visitors wanting to see the many delightful shades of the crystal clear waters – while alpinists often opt for the climbing garden or climbing the Pizol summit to get their fill of adventure.

And further down there’s more to discover on the Garmil-Geohöhenweg (highland trail) with available smartphone information, Heidi’s gondola railway for children, water-woods and bird village on the Furt, the Heidi trail or hammock woods to hang around a while, Kneipp facility for kids and storytale magic in the Pardiel region.INFORMATION

Altitude: 2227m 
Accessibility: 
Train to Bad Ragaz, bus to the Pizol rail valley station, gondola railway to Pardiel, Laufböden chairlift (2226m); or train to Sargans, bus to the Wangs/Pizolbahn valley station, gondola railway to Furt, chairlifts via Gaffia to the Pizol hut (2227m) 
View: Over St. Gallen’s Rhine Valley across to Lake Constance, the Churfirsten, Schesaplana, Prättigau and Alps of Graubünden 
Attractions: Attractive area for families with children and plenty of pleasurable hikes 
Culinary aspects: Panoramarestaurant Edelweiss (Pardiel), Laufbodenstübli, Pizolhütte (no overnight accommodation) 
Overnight stays: Berggasthaus Pizol, Berghotel Furt, Berghotel Alpina, Berghotel Graue Hörner, Berghotel Gaffia, Schneehus Valeis, Berggasthaus Schönbühl: Double and multi-bed rooms, vacation dormitories 
Groups: Berggasthaus Pizol 130 people; Hotel Furt with bowling, Hotel Alpina 120 people 
Winter: Winter sports region Pizol
Special comments: Two gondola railways and single destination on the ridge where the Pizol mountain hut stands
Reduced rate mountain rail ascent with the Swiss Travel Pass/GA travelcard.
Buy your tickets on arrival at the station.

Buy your mountain rail ascent return tickets now

Timetable and tickets [https://www.sbb.ch/en/buying/pages/fahrplan/fahrplan.xhtml?&nach=Wangs,Pizolbahn]

data.name: Lake Fälen: Fascinating Alpstein-Fjord
data.abstract: A jewel of a lake, embedded between the steep rock cliffs of Widderalpstöcke, and the peaks of the Hundstein in the north, the Altmann, Saxerfirst and the Kreuzberge mountains in the east, Lake Fälen's nearly black water and its constantly changing kaleidoscope of reflections never fails to enchant its visitors.
data.description:
There are often remnants of snow even in high summer, while gentian and alpine anemones flower in the areas with Southern exposure. A hiking trail runs along the northern shore of the lake, fishermen try their luck here and in the dog days of summer, there is even an intrepid bather or two that brave the chilly waters, at best 18° C. There is a lovely inn, the Bollenwie, a much-visited destination for hikers, mountaineers, and fishermen. Not only is the view phenomenal, but also the Rösti which makes the 2-hour-hike all the more worthwhile.

How to get there:
By publis transportation (train or postbus) or car from St. Gallen/Appenzell to Brülisau. From Brülisau there is a hiking trail leading to Lake Fälen, the hike takes 1 3/4 hours.

data.name: Old City
data.abstract: Just outside the abbey grounds lies St. Gall's Old City, which grew up around the abbey over the centuries and is marked by the flourishing textil industry as one can see looking at the loveley decorated houses with their oriels.
data.description: Wander through the narrow, winding streets with tiny boutique shops, galleries and bakeries and enjoy the friendly atmosphere of the Metropolis St. Gallen. Dine outdoors if weather permits or in one of the typical 1st floor restaurants , on cuisine as varied as Swiss, American, Spanish, Vietnamese and Thai, all within the shadow of one of Switzerland's most important abbeys.

data.name: From restaurant to restaurant in the City of St. Gall
data.abstract: This “restaurant ramble” is an exciting and varied combination of city tour and culinary discoveries at various restaurants in the City of St. Gall.
data.description:
The compact metropolis of eastern Switzerland between Lake Constance and Appenzellerland has a charming, traffic-free old town. Colourfully-painted oriel windows are a town feature. The Abbey precinct with the cathedral and Abbey Library has been accorded UNESCO World Heritage listing. 
Your tour guide will provide you with a vivid impression of St.Gallen interspersed with anecdotes and incidents from the past. And in between times, each restaurant will be serving you the courses you have selected.

data.name: Voralpen-Express
data.abstract: The gentle side of Switzerland: It’s not all 4000-metre mountains and deep ravines. On the Voralpen-Express, visitors discover a different kind of Switzerland – undulating hills, picturesque villages and lovely orchards.
data.description:
Voralpen-Express is the most appealing way to travel between Eastern and Central Switzerland. Starting from Eastern Switzerland’s urban centre of St. Gallen, whose Abbey district is a UNESCO world heritage site, the train traverses the 99 metre high Sitter viaduct and the rolling landscape of “Toggenburg”. Passing by Rapperswil and the impressive upland moor near Rothenthurm, the journey ends after a little over two hours in historic Lucerne on the shores of Lake Lucerne.
FACTS
Route: St. Gallen – Wattwil – Rapperswil – Arth Goldau – Luzern
Distance: 125 km 
Duration: 2 h 18 min
EXCURSION TIPS
St. Gallen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/destinations/st-gallen/] and surrounding area
 * Abbey district and Abbey library
 * Säntis – one of the most breathtaking panoramas of Switzerland at 2505 m a.s.l. 
 * Appenzell region – tradition is important between Bodensee and Säntis 

Rapperswil [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/destinations/rapperswil-jona/] and surrounding area
 * Rapperswil castle
 * Lake Zurich Navigation – 2 steamboats and 12 motor boats regularly navigate Lake Zurich

Lucerne [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/destinations/lucerne/]
 * Lion’s Monument – in memorial of Swiss citizens who died in 1792 during the French Revolution 
 * Lake Lucerne boat tours
 * Landscape and Animal Park Goldau – refuge for stags, wolves, lynxes and other wild animals 

FOOD & BEVERAGES
Each train has a bistro coach with catering services.TIMETABLE
All connections here [http://www.sbb.ch/en/home.html]TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

OFFERS
Book here [https://switzerlandtravelcentre.com/en/holidays/train-journeys/voralpen-express]RESERVATIONS
No seat reservation possible – free seating.

data.name: Kraftwerke Sarganserland AG
data.abstract: Kraftwerke Saganserland AG provides consumption-adjusted peak-load energy.
data.description:
The Kraftwerke Sarganserland (KSL ), which were built between 1971 and 1978, are a 98.5 per cent subsidiary of Axpo (the remaining 1.5 per cent belongs to the canton of St. Gallen). Due to their fast availability and large capacity, the KSL power plants are used to generate consumption-adjusted peak-load energy. Both the Mapragg and Sarelli power plant stages use the water inflows from an approximately 160 km2 catchment area in the Weisstannen and Cafeisen valleys and collect this water in the Gigerwald and Mapragg reservoirs. The reservoirs are a popular destination in the summer. The Mapragg reservoir can be reached from Bad Ragaz (SG) on foot in 2h 26 minutes, by public transport in 30 minutes, or by car in 17 minutes. 


 * Plant visit
 * Guided tour (min. 8 people): by arrangement (Mon–Fri) 
 * Entrance and guided tours are free of charge

data.name: Säntispark Olympics
data.abstract: The amusement park in eastern Switzerland awaits you with a wide range of games.
data.description: A wide range of games awaits you at the diverse leisure park in Abtwil near St. Gallen. Here, guests measure their skills in an Olympics. Whether bowling, billiards, snooker, table football or darts. Afterwards, there is plenty of time to sit down in the Fairplay restaurant, enjoy a drink or have a lively chat over spaghetti.

data.name: Chäserrugg – on the Churfirsten range
data.abstract: Relaxed hiking, enjoy the views of the authentic Swiss mountain world, experience world-class architecture by Herzog & de Meuron and discover gastronomy of Toggenburg.
data.description:
Whether travelling by train or car, many spot the seven summits of the Churfirsten range on passing the Walensee lake – so why not stop for once to enjoy scenic views down to the valley from a totally different angle? Easiest access comes from behind, courtesy of large carriages and the Iltios funicular railway to the Chäserrugg.

Between rocks left and right, here on the small high plateau the Rosenboden flower trail begins. And once in Toggenburg, be sure to pay a visit to the sound and sayings paths. INFORMATION

Altitude: 2262m 
Accessibility: 
Bus from Nesslau-Neu St.Johann or Buchs SG to Unterwasser (Iltiosbahn), funicular rail, from Iltios by cable car 
View: Upper Toggenburg, Säntis, Walensee lake, Glärnisch 
Attractions: Flower trail on the Rosenberg high plateau; in-depth views of the Walensee lake and Toggenburg sound path
Culinary aspects: Good home cooking with regional produce, St. Gallen Bratwurst sausages; breakfast buffets in summer 
Overnight stays: nein 
Groups: Restaurant hall for 120, Toggenburger hall 80 and sun terrace with seating for100; Infrastruktur for meetings in the Toggenburger hall 
Winter: Winter sports regionToggenburg, cable cars, mountain restaurant and Chäserrugg snow bar 
Special comments: Sunrise trips start at 5 a.m.

data.name: A cable car experience for the young – and for the young at heart!
data.abstract: Above Fanas in Prättigau, the small aerial cableway opens onto a hiking area above the fog that gets more than its fair share of sunshine, particularly during the winter. Whether you opt to savour a platter of cold cuts on the sun terrace or embark on a winter hike, the little cable car is worth a trip in itself.
data.description:
Starting at Landquart, the region of Prättigau snakes its way in a north-easterly direction into the heart of Graubünden. From the picturesque mountain village of Fanas, one of the few small aerial cableways in Graubünden opens onto a magnificent hiking area. The area is usually above the fog, even in winter, and receives above-average levels of sunshine.

The upper station of the aerial cableway lies at 1,700 metres above sea level and is the ideal starting point for various winter hikes or walks. Connoisseurs will love sitting on the sun terrace of the Sassauna mountain restaurant and tucking into a delicious platter of cold cuts as their gaze wanders over the panorama below. Here, everything is a part of the overall experience: the train, the journey and the view.
With a journey time of one hour from St. Gallen or Zurich, the charming aerial cableway is easy to get to and is an ideal refuge for those wishing to escape the fog. On sunny weekends, we recommend making a reservation and having a look at the timetable.

More information [https://www.praettigau.info/de/ausflugsziele/seilbahn-fanas]

data.name: Art in public places
data.abstract: Switzerland’s largest outdoor living room is the Stadtlounge (“City Lounge”), a project that converted the Bleicheli district into a day/night space for play, relaxation and business.
data.description: Art also adorns the university campus, with works by Arp, Richter, Giacometti and Miró. You can see outstanding design throughout the city, from buildings by the leading Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava to ornate public fountains.

data.name: City Lounge - Red Square
data.abstract: The first public lounge in Switzerland spreads out in the St.Galler Bleichi district in the open air. It is covered in red rubber granulate and is lit by artistic lighting elements. The "city lounge" by artist Pipilotti Rist and architect Carlos Martinez invites you to relax and marvel.
data.description:
The St.Galler Bleichi district is a typical shopping and office area. That there are nevertheless still people out and about until late in the evening is thanks to the airy sitting room designed by the multimedia artist Pipilotti Rist together with the architect Carlos Martinez. The great Red Square is furnished with sofas, chairs, tables, couches and a Porsche – which, like the ground, are covered in a bright red carpet of plastic granulate. 

During the day, children use the unusual city landscape for play while the employees from the surrounding businesses take breaks on the comfortable seating. In the evening, lighting elements which hang above the square like floating boulders light the scene and draw the young and young at heart into their light.

data.name: Thal viticultural trail
data.abstract: Young and old will enjoy the challenge of the viticultural trail in Thal. Afterwards, little ones will know more about their natural surroundings, while adults will have learned some fascinating facts about winegrowing.
data.description: For around two hours, this trail leads along the ridge around the southern side of the Buechberg. For children, short quiz questions are posed at the bottom of the information boards, with the answers unveiled on folding down a panel. Those who prefer to listen rather than read can scan the QR codes on the boards to access the great audio content. To gain an even deeper insight into the world of wine, tours can be booked with the winemaker Felix Lutz as your guide.

data.name: Combined ticket for the Abbey of St. Gall
data.abstract: The Abbey of St. Gall has been a UNESCO World Heritage site since 1983, and has plenty of impressive treasures just waiting to be discovered in its library, vaulted cellar and new exhibition hall.
data.description:
With the “Entire Abbey” combined ticket, you can admire all three exhibitions, including the original map of the Abbey of St. Gall from the 9th century, which is being displayed as an original for the very first time.

The map of the abbey is the earliest preserved visualisation of a monastic compound produced in the Middle Ages. It is thought to have been drawn up sometime between 819 and 826 in the monastery of Reichenau on Lake Constance, and is in the possession of the Abbey Library of St. Gall.

The combined ticket is CHF 18 for adults, and CHF 12 for students and apprentices. For children aged under 16 accompanying their parents, entry is free of charge.

data.name: Water sports on Lake Constance
data.abstract: With the largest area of any lake in Switzerland, Lake Constance has an extensive range of water sports on offer and something for everyone.
data.description: In Rorschach you can enjoy a stroll while admiring the lake from the shore or go sailing or pedalo riding. Soak up the sun at the Badehütte Rorschach or jump into the refreshing water. Here you will feel as if you have been transported back 100 years!

data.name: Creative just like Hundertwasser
data.abstract: The Market Hall Altenrhein was built following the ideas and concepts of Friendensreich Hundertwasser, the famous artist.
data.description: Gold-plated onion domes, bright colours, flowing lines, asymmetrical windows, uneven floors, colourful ceramic pillars, shady ambulatories, and roof gardens are the distinctive features of Friedensreich Hundertwasser’s architecture. However, there remains much to be done in and around the Market Hall. Use this opportunity for your team to create its own building in Hundertwasser style under expert guidance.

data.name: Broderbrunnen
data.abstract: This fountain, created by Toggenburg sculptor August Bösch and placed on the Lindenplatz in 1896, is a reminder of the times when the city was supplied with water from Lake Constance.
data.description: The group of nymphs at the centre symbolises the blessings that water brings. These are surrounded by three children riding on aquatic animals.

data.name: Drei Weieren
data.abstract: Drei Weieren (Three Ponds) are an oasis of peace in the middle of the city. The ponds, which were originally built by the monastery for their water needs with their art nouveau bath houses, are a popular destination for outings and as swimming spot.
data.description:
A sweet pond landscape stretches out in the south of the city, on a high plateau below Mount Freuden. It is the local recreation area for the city inhabitants and part of a connecting nature protection area that runs along the entire southern slope of the city. 

There are still four ponds remaining from the original five. They were dug out, or filled in as the case may be, in the period between the 17th and 20th centuries and served to provide water to put out fires during blazes and also as a water supply for the city bleaching. With the aid of a wangler, the water was pushed over the Mülegg weir into the Steinach and directed onwards into the city. 

The ponds are beloved swimming areas for the locals in summer and are a meeting point in winter for lovers of ice skating. A round trip through the pond landscape is attractive at any time of the year due to the panoramic view over the entire city.

data.name: Chocolaterie am Klosterplatz
data.description: The unique café is situated in the blue building - an exquisite location opposite the entrance to the cathedral. Chocolate aficionados will find everything their heart desires within the walls of the café, including hot chocolate and chocolate specialities. The chocolate factory shop is home to a wide range of sweet treats and great gift ideas. The Tourist Information is in the same building.

data.name: Guided Tours of the Monatery
data.abstract: Receive an unforgettable insight into the history of the Benedictine Monastery.
data.description: Receive an unforgettable insight into the colorful world of the Baroque and visit the monastery church with the Lady Chapel and the "Black Madonna". Learn all the answers about the life of the monks and visit the non-public, impressive Abbey Library.
